content: REVOLVING FUND. The United States Institute for Environmental Conflict Resolution Revolving Fund is established in the Treasury, administered by the Foundation. The Fund consists of appropriated amounts and payments. The Foundation will use the Fund for necessary expenses to operate the Institute, including salaries, administration, mediation services, and other reasonable expenses as determined by the Board. The Revolving Fund for the Institute will cover salaries, administration, mediation services, and other necessary expenses as determined by the Board. It will be separate from the Trust Fund and not subject to certain program priorities. The Secretary of the Treasury will invest any excess amounts in the Fund. The Secretary of the Treasury will invest excess amounts in the Revolving Fund in interest-bearing obligations of the United States. Investments can be made on original issue or by purchasing outstanding obligations at market price. Investments under paragraph (1) in the Revolving Fund can be acquired on original issue at the issue price or by purchasing outstanding obligations at market price. Any obligation acquired by the Fund may be sold by the Secretary of the Treasury at market price, with interest and proceeds credited back to the Fund. SEC. 11. USE OF THE INSTITUTE BY A FEDERAL AGENCY. The Morris K. Udall Scholarship and Excellence in National Environmental and Native American Public Policy Act of 1992 is amended to allow a federal agency to utilize the institute. A Federal agency can utilize the Foundation and Institute for environmental, public lands, or natural resources disputes. They can contract and pay for services, with payments going into a Revolving Fund. Notification and concurrence are required for agency actions. Payment from an executive agency on a contract shall be paid into the Revolving Fund. Agencies must notify the chairperson of the President's Council on Environmental Quality before using the Foundation or Institute for services, providing a written description of the issues and parties involved. The Foundation or Institute must be notified by agencies before using their services, with a written description of the issues and parties involved, prior efforts made to address the issues, and other relevant information. Before using the Foundation or Institute for services, agencies must notify them with details of the dispute, efforts made to resolve it, and obtain concurrence from the chairperson of the President's Council on Environmental Quality in cases involving disagreements between Federal Government agencies. SEC. 8. Authorization of appropriations for the Trust Fund and Revolving Fund. $3,000,000 allocated for fiscal year 1998 and $2,100,000 for each fiscal year from 1999 to 2002. SEC. 9. Conforming amendments. SEC. 9. CONFORMING AMENDMENTS. Amendments made to the Morris K. Udall Scholarship and Excellence in National Environmental and Native American Public Policy Act of 1992 include changing references from "Fund" to "Trust Fund" in various sections.
